2024 film by Zack Snyder

Distributed byNetflixRelease dates
April 12, 2024 (2024-04-12) (United States)
April 19, 2024 (2024-04-19) (Netflix)
Running time122 minutes[1]CountryUnited StatesLanguageEnglishBudget$166 million(shared with Part One: A Child of Fire)[2]
Rebel Moon – Part Two: The Scargiver is a 2024 American epic space opera film directed by Zack Snyder from a screenplay he co-wrote with Kurt Johnstad and Shay Hatten.[3][4][5][6] It is a direct sequel to Rebel Moon – Part One: A Child of Fire (2023) and the second part of the two-part saga. The film takes place on the moon of Veldt where Kora and the crew of warriors ventures to help the farmers to defend and fight for their home against the Motherworld. Sofia Boutella, Djimon Hounsou, Ed Skrein, Michiel Huisman, Doona Bae, Ray Fisher, Staz Nair, Fra Fee, Elise Duffy, Charlotte Maggi, Stuart Martin, Cary Elwes, and Anthony Hopkins reprise their roles from Part One: A Child of Fire.
Rebel Moon – Part Two: The Scargiver was released in select cinemas in the United States on April 12, 2024, and was released by Netflix on April 19, 2024. Much like its predecessor, it received generally negative reviews from critics. An R-rated extended cut is set for release after the film's initial release.[7]


Plot[edit]
Kora and the surviving warriors prepare to fight and defend their new homeworld Veldt against the Motherworld led by Noble.

Cast[edit]
Sofia Boutella as Kora / Arthelais, a former Imperium soldier who rallies warriors from across the galaxy to fight against the Motherworld.
Djimon Hounsou as Titus, a former general of the Imperium recruited to lead the fight against the Motherworld.
Ed Skrein as Atticus Noble, an admiral and Balisarius' right-hand man. He was killed by Kora before being resurrected by the Imperium.
Michiel Huisman as Gunnar, Kora's love interest and a farmer who joins her in her attempts to defend his homeworld Veldt.
Doona Bae as Nemesis, a cyborg swordmaster.
Ray Fisher as Darrian Bloodaxe, a warrior and Devra's brother recruited by Kora.
Staz Nair as Tarak, a nobleman-turned-blacksmith with the ability to bond with animals of nature.
Fra Fee as Regent Balisarius, a tyrant and Kora's adoptive father who seized control of the Motherworld.
Elise Duffy as Millius, a rebel fighter recruited under Darrian's command. [2]
Anthony Hopkins as the voice of Jimmy, the last member of a race of mechanical knights.[8]
Dustin Ceithamer as the body-double on the set of Jimmy
Alfonso Herrera as Cassius, Noble's team warrior.
Stuart Martin as Den, a local farmer and hunter.
Cary Elwes as the King.
Rhian Rees as the Queen.
Charlotte Maggi as Sam, a farm girl who warmly welcomes any outsiders that come to her village.[9][10]
Stella Grace Fitzgerald
Production[edit]
Development[edit]
Rebel Moon is inspired by the works of Akira Kurosawa, the Star Wars films and Heavy Metal magazines.[11] Johnstad and Snyder first started talking about creating the film in 1997.[12] The project began development as a Star Wars film that Snyder had pitched to Lucasfilm, shortly after the sale of Lucasfilm to The Walt Disney Company in 2012. This pitch was to be a more mature take on the Star Wars universe.[13]
Part Two received over $16.6 million in tax credits from the state of California for spending over $83 million on production in the state.[14]

Post-production[edit]
The titles for the two parts were revealed to be Part One: A Child of Fire and Part Two: The Scargiver, according to teaser trailers released at Gamescom in August 2023.[15][16] In March 2024, the official trailer was released.[17]

Music[edit]
Composer Tom Holkenborg returns to compose the score for Part Two: The Scargiver, who served as composer for Part One: A Child of Fire. In March 2024, it was announced that a track list named "Songs of the Rebellion" will be released, based on the characters from the Rebel Moon universe. It features several artists, including Jessie Reyez, Tokischa, Tainy, Aespa, Tokimonsta, Black Coffee, and Kordhell. It was released on April 5, 2024.[18]

Release[edit]
Rebel Moon – Part Two: The Scargiver was released in select theaters in the United States for a week on April 12, 2024, and was released by Netflix on April 19, 2024.[19]

Reception[edit]
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 16% of 50 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 3.5/10. The website's consensus reads: "Less a course correction than a compounding of everything that tangled up its predecessor, The Scargiver is an uninvolving space opera full of flat notes."[20] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 36 out of 100, based on 21 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable" reviews.[21]

Future[edit]
In April 2024, co-writer Kurt Johnstad announced that though original plans were for a trilogy of movies, the franchise will eventually consist of a total of six films; explaining that the stories for each original installment have been expanded into two parts. The writer stated that the treatments are completed for the third and fourth movie and Snyder is currently writing the third film.[22] On the same day, Snyder stated that the total number of films in the series will either be four or six, depending on whether or not the second and third entries of the trilogy each get split into a two-part movie as well. [23]
